docs.abstract: Microsoft Corp presents relatively upbeat picture of company at its annual meeting in Seattle despite bumpy year in stock market, uncertain future in courts and shareholder dissent over some of its political contributions; company's executives say personal computers will remain company's focus (M)

headline.main: Microsoft Hears Little Criticism at Its Annual Meeting

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a bumpy year in the stock market, an uncertain future in the courts and shareholder dissent over some of its political contributions, the Microsoft Corporation presented a relatively upbeat picture of the company at its annual meeting here today. While Microsoft, the world's largest software company, is promoting initiatives built around cellular phones, digital cameras and televisions, the company's leaders said their focus remained where it had always been: on personal computers. ''Some of our competitors will tell you that this will be a world without personal computers some day,'' Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive, said. ''They're wrong.''
docs.snippet: Despite a bumpy year in the stock market, an uncertain future in the courts and shareholder dissent over some of its political contributions, the Microsoft Corporation presented a relatively upbeat picture of the company at its annual meeting here...

docs.abstract: America Online earned $345 million in third quarter, up from $181 million a year earlier, increase of 91 percent; its revenue grew 34 percent, to $2 billion; Time Warner earned $85 million, down 76 percent from year earlier; revenue was $6.9 billion, up 3 percent (M)

headline.main: AOL and Time Warner Slightly Beat Profit Estimates

docs.lead_paragraph: With just a month or two before their proposed merger is expected to be consummated, America Online and Time Warner each posted quarterly earnings yesterday that were largely as expected. But the top management of both companies spent much of the day trying to counter the pessimism on Wall Street. They argued that they would not be hurt by any slowdown in advertising by Internet companies and indeed had already discovered ways that their combination would accelerate their growth.
docs.snippet: With just a month or two before their proposed merger is expected to be consummated, America Online and Time Warner each posted quarterly earnings yesterday that were largely as expected. But the top management of both companies spent much of the ...

docs.abstract: Priceline.com's affiliate that lets consumers bid for groceries and gasoline online is abandoned because it cannot raise enough money to stay in business; group of investors stand to lose most of $360 million they put into venture, Priceline WebHouse Club, which is privately held; WebHouse founder Jay S Walker concedes he will lose most or all of $179 million he invested in WebHouse; Walker's shares of Priceline are valued at $220 million compared with $8 billion in April 1999; Walker says he harbors no ill will toward investors who refused to continue pumping money into his WebHouse venture; graph; photo (M)

headline.main: Priceline's WebHouse Club Abandoned as Investors Balk

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most ambitious efforts to use the Internet to transform a big business, Priceline.com's affiliate that lets consumers bid for groceries and gasoline, was abandoned yesterday because it could not raise enough money to stay in business. A group of investors stand to lose most of the $360 million they put into the venture, the Priceline WebHouse Club, which is privately held.
docs.snippet: One of the most ambitious efforts to use the Internet to transform a big business, Priceline.com's affiliate that lets consumers bid for groceries and gasoline, was abandoned yesterday because it could not raise enough money to stay in business.  ...

docs.abstract: FBI arrests Mark S Jakob on charges that he issued fake e-mail press release warning that Emulex Corp's chief executive had resigned and that it earnings had been overstated; Securities and Exchange Commission files civil complaint against Jakob, seeking to freeze his assets and recoup what it calls $240,000 in illegal profits; photo (M)

headline.main: Suspect Is Arrested in Fake News Case

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark S. Jakob made a big bet in mid-August that shares in Emulex, a maker of communications equipment, would decline, federal prosecutors say. Instead, Emulex soared, leaving him with a paper loss of almost $100,000 in just a week. So Mr. Jakob, a 23-year-old former student at El Camino Community College in Torrance, Calif., took matters into his own hands, according to the government. On the evening of Aug. 24, he sent a fake press release by e-mail to Internet Wire, a Los Angeles service where he had previously worked, warning that Emulex's chief executive had resigned and its earnings were overstated. The next morning, just as financial markets opened, Internet Wire distributed the damaging release to news organizations and Web sites.

docs.abstract: Michael Robertson tells federal court in New York that he believed he was acting legally when he created MP3.com, database of thousands of copyrighted record albums; damage phase of trial begins after failure of negotiations with Universal Music Group (S)

headline.main: Chief of MP3.com Testifies in Music Copyright Hearing

docs.lead_paragraph: With his Internet music start-up facing potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in damages for copyright violations, the head of MP3.com told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that he believed he was acting legally when he created an online database of thousands of copyrighted record albums. The testimony from Michael Robertson, MP3.com's chief executive, came at the first day of hearings in a trial pitting his company, a San Diego-based start-up, against the Seagram Company's Universal Music Group, the world's largest record company. The trial began after negotiations over the weekend failed to produce a settlement.
docs.snippet: With his Internet music start-up facing potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in damages for copyright violations, the head of MP3.com told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that he believed he was acting legally when he created an onli...

docs.abstract: American Assistance for Cambodia, nonprofit group run by Bernard Krisher, creates permanent Internet connection to Robib, Cambodia, rural village where average per capita income is about $37 a month; project will provide computer education and Web access to a village school attended by 400 children and support creation of small woven-silk industry in the village; selling silk scarves and table runners over the Internet might generate $2,000 a month in revenue; project shows potential of Internet to foster economic development in rural areas, narrowing disparity between urban and rural incomes and perhaps reversing migration of rural poor to cities; photos (M)

headline.main: It Takes a World Wide Web to Raise a Village

docs.lead_paragraph: Overlooked in last month's Group of 8 discussions about the challenge of a growing ''digital divide'' between the information rich and the data deprived was the work of Bernard Krisher, a 69-year-old former journalist who is trying to bring the Internet to one of the poorest regions in Asia. Most recently, Mr. Krisher's nonprofit group, American Assistance for Cambodia, has been toiling to create a permanent Internet connection to a primary school in the village of Robib, a cluster of six rural communities in north central Cambodia, more than a nine-hour drive from Phnom Penh. [On Monday, the group plans to announce that it has succeeded.]
docs.snippet: Overlooked in last month's Group of 8 discussions about the challenge of a growing ''digital divide'' between the information rich and the data deprived was the work of Bernard Krisher, a 69-year-old former journalist who is trying to bring the In...

docs.abstract: Go.com Inc, Internet unit of the Walt Disney Company, reports fiscal third quarter loss of $272 million, compared with loss of $251.1 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline.main: Go.Com Says Losses Grew in 3rd Quarter

docs.lead_paragraph: Go.com Inc., the Internet unit of the Walt Disney Company, said today that its loss widened in the fiscal third quarter as the company spent heavily to refocus its business on entertainment. Go.com, which includes the Go Network group of Internet sites and ABCNews.com, reported a net loss of $272.2 million, or $1.75 a share, including amortization of intangible assets. A year ago, it lost $251.5 million, or $1.64 a share.

docs.abstract: US District Court Judge Marilyn Patel's preliminary injunction prohibiting Napster from offering online access to songs whose copyrights are owned by major records labels is seen as blow to those who had hoped to build business around trading of copyrighted music over Internet, but widespread copying of music is showing no signs of abating; Web users are swarming to alternative music services, and since many of these are decentralized and noncommerical, they are likely to be much harder for recording industry to attack (M)

headline.main: For Many Fans of Online Music, U.S. Court Ruling Is Call to Arms

docs.lead_paragraph: It was around 8 p.m. on Wednesday when Joe Frost heard that a federal judge had issued an order that effectively shut down Napster. By 11 p.m., he had linked his computer to one of several underground networks that allow users to do the same thing as the popular Internet music-swapping service does, only without providing a central target. Like many of Napster's millions of users, Mr. Frost, a 23-year-old systems administrator in San Francisco, did not see the court's ruling as a victory for copyright law or a defeat for a particular company. He saw it as a call to arms. ''I wanted to get more involved in keeping free music distribution alive,'' Mr. Frost said.
docs.snippet: It was around 8 p.m. on Wednesday when Joe Frost heard that a federal judge had issued an order that effectively shut down Napster. By 11 p.m., he had linked his computer to one of several underground networks that allow users to do the same thing...

docs.abstract: Bertelsmann AG will buy CDNow Inc, struggling online music retailer, for $117 million in cash; deal will give Bertelsmann recognized brand in online music sales as it tries to expand its electronic commerce business (M)

headline.main: Bertelsmann to Buy Struggling Online Music Retailer

docs.lead_paragraph: Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, will buy CDNow Inc., the struggling online music retailer, for $117 million in cash, Bertelsmann said yesterday. The deal, worth $3 for each CDNow share, will give Bertelsmann a recognized brand in online music sales as it tries to expand its electronic commerce business. For CDNow, the merger ends the company's extensive search for a partner, which intensified in March after a merger deal with Columbia House fell through.

docs.abstract: Small businesses are 'renting' business software from growing number of Internet companies known as ASP's--application service providers; ASP's use Internet to offer range of software and technology-related services that would otherwise be performed by internal departments at customer's company; big corporate computing departments are also striking deals with ASP's to shed at least some of their applications; photo; graph (M)

headline.main: Renting Software and the Skills to Go With It

docs.lead_paragraph: For the last year, Rave Sports, a small, privately held maker of inflatable water trampolines that is based in St. Paul, has been scrambling to keep up with its sales. The last thing its executives wanted was the expense of hiring a computing staff to manage the company's accounting and sales management systems. So as a lot of other small-business executives do these days, Rave's chief financial officer, Pat Golden, decided to ''rent'' its main business software from one of a growing number of Internet companies known as A.S.P.'s.
